Scale model of London at The Building Centre, on Store Street. This view is looking northeast, from Westminster (Big Ben etc) over the South Bank toward the City, with the new Olympic Village in the distance. <a href"http:www.buildingcentre.co.ukgalleriesgalleries.asp" rel"nofollow">The Building Centre: Galleries page<a> <a href"http:london.randomness.org.ukwiki.cgi?Building_Centre" rel"nofollow">london.randomness.org.ukwiki.cgi?Building_Centre<a> <a href"http:www.cityofsound.comblog200508modeling_new_lo.html" rel"nofollow">City of Sound: Modeling New London<a> <a href"http:www.newlondonarchitecture.orgaboutnla.php" rel"nofollow">New London Architecture: About NLA<a>

uk greatbritain bridge england bus london eye public westminster architecture square europe publictransit publictransportation unitedkingdom britain eu londoneye parliament bigben parliamentsquare transportation gb vehicle masstransit 2008 whitehall doubledeckerbus londonbus thatlondon cameranikond50 exif:flashflashdidnotfire exif:exposure0005sec1200 exif:iso_speed200 exif:focal_length40mm exif:aperturef71 exif:exposure_bias06ev camera:makenikoncorporation camera:modelnikond50 meta:exif1257957036 exif:orientationhorizontalnormal exif:filenamedscjpg meta:exif1350407154
London Eye, Parliament, Big Ben & Hungerford Bridge while crossing Waterloo Bridge from tour bus roof deck

In the middle foreground is the top of the Bank of America tower; behind it to the left is the squat, round, glass Roy Thompson Hall opera house. Up a bit from the Opera House is the Hilton, then back from that a bit is the Sheraton, and facing the Sheraton is the New City Hall towers. The tall white one to the right is First Canadian Place, and the red one at the right edge is Scotia Plaza. I've not bothered to look up what most of the ones in the cluster in the middle are. By all means feel free to cross-check a <a href"http:maps.google.commaps?fq&hlen&geocode&qcn+tower&ieUTF8&ll43.64519,-79.384267&spn0.012267,0.016887&th&z16">satellite map<a> to get a fuller sense of the view here. In any case, even in spite of the smog, I think the view here goes out for several miles to the north-northwest. On a clear day I bet you can see all the way to the North Pole from here. I bet you can.
